author: sky.cactus
content:
https://discordapp.com/channels/595666850260713488/749160974506000444/753885525513076748
<@456226577798135808> I'm surprised no one has said `ECC easily reversible`.

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps too technical for Twitter?

author: sky.cactus
content: I actually had a dream last night where I "cracked" ECC (meaning, I figured out how to go the other direction and find a private key from a public key) and I didn't know what to do with that information.  Should I steal some money and exit before anyone else figured it out, or should I do some kind of responsible disclosure?  If I did responsible disclosure (prove to people it was possible but not specifics of how), how would I protect myself from the government agents that would certainly try to hunt me down and wrench me for the secret?

author: gichiba
content: This would be a great thriller

author: sky.cactus
content: I would watch it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Mr. Robot type movie perhaps?

author: gichiba
content: yeah... I wonder if the RSA guys had similar thoughts

author: gichiba
content: because they were actually the second to invent it; the first mathematician was a guy named Clifford Cocks

author: gichiba
content: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSA_(cryptosystem)#History

author: gichiba
content: but it was immediately classified

author: gichiba
content: another version of this would be kind of a primer-esque movie about physicists that make a working garage-based quantum computer

author: sky.cactus
content: Meaning the government knew about the backdoor and didn't tell anyone?

author: gichiba
content: meaning they understood the potential for what widespread and ubiquitous encryption could mean for global espionage

author: gichiba
content: and tried to keep it from public view until it was independently made public by the 3 mathematicians R, S, and A

author: gichiba
content: then it was too late

author: sky.cactus
content:
> yeah... I wonder if the RSA guys had similar thoughts
Oh, sorry.  I thought you were talking about the people who "cracked" (not quite the right term here) RSA.

author: sky.cactus
content: (not actually a crack, just a bug in a very popular library IIRC)

author: gichiba
content: oh I was going to say, that'd be big news!
